DataElement.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (MSAS) 10-18 Past Week How Often Feel Irritable Score 4 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Person's stated observation in the past week of how often they were feeling irritable, using a four-point Likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (MSAS) 10-18 Past Week How Often Feel Irritable Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version._The most recent week, including today._A question about how often an individual feels or felt irritable._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version.

Concepts.definition: A patient-rated questionnaire designed to evaluate the prevalence, characteristics, and distress to children with cancer aged 10-18. This 30-question instrument was adapted from a previously-validated adult version.

Property.preferredName: Past Week How Often Feel Irritable Score
Property.preferredDefinition: The most recent week, including today.:A question about how often an individual feels or felt irritable.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: The most recent week. May include the present day.
A question about how often an individual feels or felt irritable.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

DataElementConcept.origin: MSAS 10-18:  Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (10-18). J. Collins, et al. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management. 2000 May; 19(5): 363-377

ValueDomain.preferredName: Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (10-18) Frequency Score 4 Point Scale
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A scale for the subjective scoring of event frequency that ranges from 1: Almost Never to 4: Almost Always designed for use with the Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (MSAS) 10-18.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A response indicating that something happens or happened almost all of the time.

Concepts.definition: A response indicating that something happens or happened almost all of the time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer of strong agreement.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer describing a great amount or extent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: From time to time, but not continually or always.

Concepts.definition: From time to time, but not continually or always.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer that something rarely happens.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer that something rarely happens.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

Concepts.definition: An ordered reference standard used to measure incremental changes.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Quality of Life Measures (Patient Reported Outcomes - Health Related Quality of Life)

ReferenceDocuments.name: How often did you have the fe
ReferenceDocuments.description: How often did you have the feelings of being irritable?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Using PRO/HRQoL Measures
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data element is part of a full set of items that comprise a PRO/HRQoL measure. The full set must be used without any changes to the questions or value set in order to retain the validity and reliability associated with the measure. The URL citation is provided so that caDSR users can obtain materials related to instructions for administering and/or scoring the measure. Changes may not be made to these documents. Where an investigator wants to use single Patient Reported Outcome items that are integrated into a study, DCP review is required prior to inclusion of the item on a case report form.

DataElement.origin: MSAS 10-18:  Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale (10-18). J. Collins, et al. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management. 2000 May; 19(5): 363-377
